transcripts.text: I don't think about it, I've moved on.  Weak!  He called me weak!

Prime Minister Justin Trudeau facing a lot of criticism from all corners for what was really a pretty gaftastic weekend.  He scored a hat trick of headlines he probably didn't want.  Here's the first one sitting down with Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and more than once he got a little confused.  which country he was talking about messed up Japan with China.  Take a listen to this one.
on the occasion of 90 years of diplomatic relations between Canada and China, Canada and Japan.
And as if that wasn't enough, well, at least he apologized for that flub.  Then he did it again, and he didn't even really seem to catch himself.
The tremendous friendship that we celebrate every day between Canada and China.  Thank you, Shinzo.

Then after that, video surfaced of Justin Trudeau at one of the sandbagging sites to deal with all the rising water levels we've seen in parts of our country.  One volunteer was not happy with the extended photo op that Justin Trudeau was taking, thought it made him a rather disingenuous volunteer.
I volunteered, but I was in a rut for an hour waiting while you were here with a photo op.  The most insincere thing I've ever seen.

And as Canadians debate whether or not Trudeau was right or wrong to have that photo op, whether the volunteer, quite angry, you saw him there, whether or not he has a point, the rest of the world, particularly Americans, are now talking about Justin Trudeau after his appearance on The Simpsons Sunday night.
Oh, I am really, really sorry about what our president called you.
I don't think about it.  I've moved on.  Weak.  He called me weak.  Absolutely.  Let me ask you, does this look weak?
Seriously?  Wow, that is impressive.  Uh, what's your tie?
So listen, if I could just ask you one question about the SNC-Lavalin scandal.

Ouch, that's got to hurt.  I know the Simpsons aren't in the ratings glory days that they once were at, but still, when the world was previously praising you and now they're laughing at you, that's not a good look.  So what do you think about these gaffes?  Should we cut Justin Trudeau some slack or are these big problems that just continue to show that his support is eroding both here and internationally?  Let us know what you think.  Send us your comments, comment on YouTube, Facebook, and share the video.
